conclusion: Mass of block A: m_A = 1 kg
Mass of block B: m_B = 2 kg
Maximum static friction force between A and B: f_{s,max} = 1 N
Coefficient of kinetic friction between B and ground: μ_k = 0.1

premise: For blocks A and B to remain relatively stationary, the friction force between them must be sufficient to prevent relative motion.
conclusion: The friction force between A and B must prevent relative motion.
Block A has a weight of W_A = m_A g = 1 × 10 = 10 N (downward).
Normal force from B on A: N_{BA} = 10 N (upward).
Horizontal friction force from B on A: f (directed opposite to potential relative motion).
Block B has a weight of W_B = m_B g = 2 × 10 = 20 N (downward).
Normal force from ground on B: N_{ground} = W_A + W_B = 10 + 20 = 30 N (upward).
Normal force on A from B: N_{BA} = 10 N (downward).
Friction force between B and A: f (opposite direction to f on A).
Friction force between B and ground: f_{ground}.

premise: When the applied force F increases, there are two possibilities: 1. Blocks A and B move together without relative motion 2. Block B moves relative to A
conclusion: If net force trying to cause relative motion is greater than 1 N, blocks will slide relative to each other.

premise: The only horizontal force on A is the friction force f from B. For A to accelerate with B (no relative motion), this friction force must equal m_A × a.
conclusion: Friction force f must equal m_A × a for no relative motion.

premise: F - f_{ground} = (m_A + m_B)a and f_{ground} = μ_k × N_{ground}
